title: Fire Protection Conclave
description: Large group of men from a newspaper photo-names below picture. Typed text: Main Heading: FIRE PROTECTION CONCLAVE - Association operators, PFI foremen met with CTPA and PTPA personnel in June to review summer fire plans on a million acres of forest tree farms and timber growing areas. Chief Fire Warden A. B. Curtis presided at the meeting and Leonard Floan and Geo. Rauch, PFI vice presidents, spoke to the group. Description: Front row: Although not all are identifiable, in the front row kneeling are Leonard Floan, Bill Walker, Clarence Nordby, Wallace Boll, Dwain Chilberg, Mel Bradbury, Tommy Femrite, John Grogan, Bill Wheeler, Al Hanson, Bill Marr, Don Hinton, Bill Cummings, George Harlan, Levon Chase, George Rauch, and A. B. Curtis. List of Names: Royce Cox, Mick Koppang, Doug Curtis, Bob Tondevold, Tim Edwards, Frank Rand채ll, Mervin Johnson, Whitey Welland, Walt Fields, A. B. Cox, Mick Koppang, Doug Curtis, Bob Tondevold, Tim Edwards, Frank Rand채ll, Mervin Johnson, Whitey Welland, Walt Fields, A. B. Royse Cox, Mick Koppang, Doug Larry Arneson, George Kolasa, Art Schultz, Frank Cash, Harvey Spears, Clem Pederson, USFS fire control officer, Chuck Toops, Guy Graham, Gordon Dickinson, Elmer Bardwell, Owen Goertzen, Carl DeWard, Gordon Thiessen, Vern Robinson, and Hap Petterson. Date (handwritten): 7-30-64.

title: Catholic Church Group
description: Large gathering of people arrayed along the side of the white framed church (St. Catherines original building). The occasion was the first communion, and the donor is one of the little girls in a big hat on the right end, (the fourth over with her chin in her hands).
original_description: Later moved and became the mormon church, and now belongs to a private party (on Fourth St, across from the elementary school playground).
image_alt_text: A large group of people gathered in front of a building with arched windows, possibly a church, with trees on either side. The group includes adults and children, dressed in different styles of clothing.

title: Congregational Church (1980's)
description: First Congregational Church taken several years before its demolition in the early 1980's. The sign near the entrance reads: "Community Congregational Church... Church School... 10:00 A.M. Worship 11:00 A.M."
original_description: The name had recently been changed from the Priest River Congregational-United Church of Christ back to its original name of the Community Congregational Church, after a disagreement with the national United Churches of Christ. The church was organized in 1901 and this building was dedicated in Nov. 1902. After the congregation moved into a new building in 1980, the Trinity Baptists used this building for awhile. In 1919 it was used as a hospital for victims of the flu epidemic.
image_alt_text: A church building with a tall bell tower featuring arched openings. The entrance has a small roofed porch with steps leading up to double doors. There are large windows with decorative designs above them. A sign in front of the church reads "Community Congregational Church." Shrubs and trees are planted around the building. The sign near the entrance reads: "Community Congregational Church... Church School... 10:00 A.M. Worship 11:00 A.M."
subject: churches; religion

title: Sunday School 1912
description: Priest River Congregational Sunday School. Vivienne Beardmore's the little girl in the big hat standing near center of photo behind 3rd child, George Beardmore seated in front in a row of seated children. Josephine (Gumaer? writing unreadable) is lady in big black hat. "She looks like an English admiral (Jeanne) at right of doorway on right side of photo.

The building has large windows with decorative panes.

title: Anselmo Ranch
description: A wide-open farmland scene with two cows grazing in the foreground. Charles Anselmo, the first Italian to arrive at Priest River (with Mike Presta) settled on a ranch east of town that is now known as the Kaniksu Stock Ranch and is still owned and operated by Anselmos. This Picture, made from a 1930 calendar, shows the ranch before its big red barn and the current buildings were constructed.
image_alt_text: A wide-open farmland scene with two cows grazing in the foreground. There is a line of trees bordering the landscape, with buildings nestled among them in the middle distance. The ground appears flat and expansive. The text at the bottom of the image reads: "FARM SCENE NEAR PRIEST RIVER. THE NATURE OF THESE LANDS AND THE CLIMATIC CONDITIONS HERE ARE MOST ADMIRABLY SUITED TO THE CULTURE OF FRUIT, HAY, POTATOES AND OTHER FARM PRODUCTS."
subject: agriculture; farms; farm houses; homesteads

title: Van Dever Homestead
description: Van Dever Homestead at Priest Lake. A group of seven people, including men, women, and children, are posed outside a wooden cabin.
image_alt_text: A group of seven people, including men, women, and children, are posed outside a wooden cabin. Two men are standing with rifles, accompanied by two dogs. One woman is holding a baby, while another two women and two children are sitting on the ground. The cabin has animal skins hanging and antlers mounted above the door, and is surrounded by trees.
subject: homesteads; cabins (buildings); firearms; women; children (people by age group); Canis (genus); dogs; pelts (animal skins)
source: Marylyn Cork Collection, Priest River Library

title: Men Carrying Deer
description: Three men holding upside down deer carcasses, a boy and dog at left, and a fourth man with rifle across his arms in the back. Boy at left is Clarence Herr, Jr. Next to him in front is Chris Butler, then George Storro & Howard Koffel. Jed Hamshar is standing behind Storro.
original_description: Identified by Lois Harold, who has a copy of the picture. She said it was taken by C.W. Herr, a photographer, father of Clarence, Jr. She dated the picture by guessing the age of the boy, born in 1897. Ellen Linton thought "Koffel" might be her father, W.J. Brumley.
image_alt_text: Five men standing in a wooded area, each holding rifles and carrying deer. A young boy stands with a dog in the foreground, holding a rifle. Trees and underbrush fill the background.
subject: hunting; firearms; deer; Cervidae (family)
creator: C.W.Herr
source: Marylyn Cork Collection, Priest River Library

title: Hunting Party
description: Left to right: Shorty Peterkin, Fred Knowlton, Harvey Wright, Billy Jachetta, James Carr, Roy Kenyon and Bill Dodge. They are holding a pole with a doe tied to it. Mary Hill, niece of Jim Carr, says these men are identified incorrectly. Dodge is first, Carr is #3, then Jachetta, Wright & Kenyon. She didn't know Peterkin & Knowlton so doesn't know which is which. (Note indicated the photo was taken before WW1.)
image_alt_text: A group of eight men standing in a line in front of a brick wall. They are holding a hunting rifle and an animal hanging upside down from a wooden pole. The men are wearing hats and formal or work attire.
subject: hunting; firearms

title: Mighty Hunters
description: Truck with four antlered bucks and two does draped over the bed and eight men and boys in background, and also two dogs.

Shull. The man next to the cab in possibly John Scribner. (Note indicating the date is approximately 1928-1930.)

title: Clarence Sutliff & Grizzly
description: Clarence Sutliff standing, arms extended to the sides, in front of a 7-foot grizzly hide. Bear was one of two large grizzlies Sutliff, Roger Billings and Neil Meyer shot at Hughes Meadows. This photograph appeared in the February 1933 edition of Outdoor Life. Picture donated by Billings' daughter. Back of picture is inscribed: "Clarence Sutliff with the first grizzley--hide 7ft. from tail tip to muzzle."
image_alt_text: A man standing in a yard with his arms outstretched, holding a large bear hide behind him. There is a wooden fence and a ladder in the background.
subject: hunting; bears; Ursus arctos (species)
source: Marylyn Cork Collection, Priest River Library

title: Clarence Sutliff & Grizzly Bear
description: Roger Billings wearing a hat sitting in a forested area with a large bear lying in front of them. Roger Billings and Neil Meyer at Hughes Meadows.
original_description: Story written up for the Feb. 1933 edition of Outdoor Life. This was the second bear killed, the one that almost killed Billings. Photo bears the following inscription on the back written by Billings: "Clarence Sutliff with grizzly bear killed by himself, myself and Neil Meyer: may 26, 1921. 5 fatal shots out of 7 hits. 303 Savage, 30-30 Winchester, 32 Remington pump. This is the bear that jumped me. Hughes Meadows, Boundary Co., Ida." Marilyn Cork wrote a "Pot Pourri" column about this event for the Oct. 14, 1987 edition of the Priest River Times.
image_alt_text: A person wearing a hat is sitting in a forested area with a large bear lying in front of them. A rifle is resting on the bear. Text on photo reads "See Back".
subject: hunting; bears; Ursus arctos (species)
source: Marylyn Cork Collection, Priest River Library
digital_collection: Marylyn Cork Priest River Historical Collection
rights: In copyright, educational use permitted. Educational use includes non-commercial reproduction of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes. title: Billings & Meyer with Grizzly Bear
description: Billings (on the left) and Meyer with the carcass of the first of two bears killed by them and Clarence Sutliff at Hughes Meadows.
original_description: Story later appeared in the Feb. 1933 edition of Outdoor Life. Inscription written by Roger W. Billings appears on the back of photo as follows: "Our first bear. His full size doesn't show because the body is sunk into the water & mud which at this place is ankle deep. The other one was slightly larger..."
image_alt_text: Two men are crouching in a grassy field, each holding a rifle. In front of them lies a large bear with its mouth open. There are mountains and trees in the background. The text at the bottom of the image reads "Roger Billings" on the left and "Neil Meyer" on the right.

title: The Boys Who Built The School
description: The WPA crew which built the high school on Hwy 2, (now Priest River Jr High). A large group of men standing on the steps of a building with two signs in front of them. Some of the men are holding a sign that reads, "And now... the boys who built the school." Another sign reads, "A WPA Project," with details about a school construction project.
original_description: The WPA crew which built the high school on Hwy 2, (now Priest River Jr High). It was donated by a gentleman from Laclede who called me (Marilyn) and whose name I forgot and who then left the picture at the Intermountain Citizen Office. He said his father or uncle was in it. Partial ID's: Frank Bongorino (Bongioni) (Bonji), in bib overalls & leaning on the sign in the front row. 2nd row: 2nd man, Henry Brown, above the "o" in "project", with a shock of red hair & suspenders, George Mack, John Shawgo to his right. 3rd row: extreme left with ribbon looped behind his head, Willie Hoop; extreme right, white hair, Slim Ferris; to his left, Oscar Derrick (tentative). 4th row: 3rd from left, short man with dark hair standing in front of tall man in a white shirt, Cliff Bossio, to his left, John Krizenesky. 5th row: extreme left, Max Salesky; last row, 3rd from left, Nick Dalebout, 2nd from left, Cliff Hill, foreman. In the 4th row, the man wearing the hat is possibly Ray Ingram, and Hugh Gillespie (Gillaspie) is supposed to be in the 5th row (next to last row), but I (Marilyn) don't know which one he is. In front, the third man from the left, wearing a tie & holding the small sign is George Hartman, a brother of Mrs. Joe Bombino.
image_alt_text: A large group of men standing on the steps of a building with two signs in front of them. "- Sign near the center: "A WPA PROJECT." - Below that: "PRIEST RIVER SCHOOL CONSTRUCTION SPONSORED BY INDEPENDENT SCHOOL DIST NO 13." - At the bottom: "WORK PROJECTS ADMINISTRATION FEDERAL WORKS AGENCY." - Sign to the left: "AND NOW- THE BOYS WHO BUILT THE SCHOOL."
organizations: WPA Crews; Priest River Public Schools
subject: education
source: Marylyn Cork Collection, Priest River Library

title: Peninsula School Group
description: A group of children and an adult wearing costumes, standing in front of a wooden building.
original_description: Group of children in costume and their teacher with the old Peninsula school behind them. The occasion was Washington's Birthday celebration. Left to right, the children are washington's black servant, Louise Dunn; colonial man, Edward Hamshar; Marquis de Lafayette, June Smith; George Washington, Milton Wallace; Martha Washington, Ethel Smith; Betsy Ross, Lucille Dunn; colonial woman, Lois Hamshar; colonial child, Laura Dunn; Indian, Grace Smith. The teacher was Marie Scibness. Donor grace Smith Stauffer was seven years old. The school house burned down in the 1931 fire, was replaced by building that still stands.

title: First School Group
description: A large group of children standing in front of Priest River's first school building with an American flag draped behind them.
original_description: Priest River's first school was a log building probably located near the confluence of the Priest and the Pend Oreille on the Priest's east bank. Rudolph Torelle, the first teacher, standing with his head in front of the last two stripes on the flag. Caroline Van Dorn is standing in front of Torelle, in the wide white collar. Nora and Agnes Murray are on her left. Vernon Stewart is the curly haired, blonde boy on the left end of the 2nd row, Glenn Stewart is on the right end. Leila Porter is the blonde who is number 3 in the first row, and Mandy Caprai (Long) is the dark haired girl standing at the right end. The older males were mostly Italian immigrants in school to learn English. Front row left to right: standing, Vernon Stewart; seated, Walter Shipley, Dude Lythman, Leila Stewart (Porter), Anna Keyser (Lawson), Cassie Judge, Dora Judge (LaMotte), Rosella Murray (Bryant), Mary Anselmo, Anna Feary and standing, Amanda Caprai (Lang). Center row: Vic Murray, Bert Lemley, John Judge, Alvin Canton, Gus Lythman, Alma Lythman, Carrie Stewart, (Van Dorn), Nora Murray, Agnes Murray, Alice Newcombe (Murray), and Glenn Stewart. Back row: John Murray, Joe Saccomano, Charles Feary, Alfred Feary, Albert N Torelle (Teacher), Frank s Mauro, Thomas Judge, Frank Jachetta, Alexander Judge and Henry Keyser.
subject: education; schools (buildings); children (people by age group)

title: 1906 Graduation
description: A group of eight people stands on the porch of Priest River's first school building.
original_description: Five young ladies, three young men and their teacher, standing in front of a frame school building, which donor thinks was located just north of the senior citizen building, about where Polly Week's house is. The girls are Irene danforth, Mary Carr (Mary Will's grandmother), Mabel Johnson (Marte Cliff's grandmother) Lily Henkel and Harriet Wyatt. The boys are Billy Jachetta, Vernon Stewart, Guy Maygar and the teacher, professor W.J. Wood. Doner thought the picture was eighth grade graduation (Vernon Stewart was Lyle's dad), but Mary Will says she thinks it was a 10th grade graduation picture. That would make Vernon's age of 17 come out about right.
image_alt_text: A group of eight people stands on the porch of a wooden building. Four women wearing long dresses with flowers pinned to them are in the front row. Behind them, four men in suits, three of whom hold rolled documents, are positioned.

title: Log School House
description: "Davis school on the Peninsula." A small log cabin with a wooden shingle roof stands in an open area under a cloudy sky.
original_description: George Davis built it for a bunkhouse in 1932 but it was in use as a schoolhouse in 1933-34. A man named Hustead apparently purchased the land it set on from the Humbird Lumber Company. More recent owners were a Crandall, a Chilcote and Frank Hammons. The building was eventually moved to Crowell Loop and is still in use as a private dwelling, according to Jewel Hammons. School district was known as district 56; It couldn't have been in existence very long. October 31st 1989: interviewed Goldie Jackson after whom the school was named she says it was Jackson never Davis. Walt Daley had told me Davis this building was the first Jackson school confirmed by the other peninsula residents Davis did apparently never own it.
image_alt_text: A small log cabin with a wooden shingle roof stands in an open area under a cloudy sky. Pieces of wood and debris are scattered on the ground around the cabin, and a few chickens are near the structure.
subject: education; schools (buildings); cabins (buildings); chickens; Gallus gallus (species)

title: Log School, Teacher and Students
description: 11 children and their teacher posed in the doorway of Davis school.
original_description: Log building mistakenly labeled peninsula school by Chuck Peterson. Walt Daily identified this group as follows; back row, Flora Dailey Cary, Rachel Dailey Cary; 2nd row, Harold Dailey, John Davis, Marvin Jackson, Barbara Davis, Ruth White Adams, teacher; front row, Walter Dailey, Ralph Comfort, Phil Stearns, Leland Comfort, Mavis Stearns. The school was located at the present Jewell (Frank) Hammons' ranch and was used until the Jackson schoolhouse was built (1936-37) -- according to Walt Dailey. 10-31-89 Interviewed Goldie Jackson who said this was the first Jackson school apparently named after her, never called Davis, although Davis apparently once owned the building. Walt Dailey had told me (Marilyn) Davis.

title: Teacher-Student group
description: 11 children and their teacher pose in outside of the Davis school.
original_description: 11 students and their teacher, apparently taken on the same day as one-21 (same clothing worn). Walt Dailey identified as follows; back row, Harold Dailey, Flora (Daily) Carey, (Rachel Dailey) Carey; 2nd row Walter Dailey, John Davis, Marvin Jackson, Barbara Davis, Ruth White (Adams) teacher; front row, Ralph Comfort, Phil Stearns, Leland Comfort, Mavis Stearns. 10-31-89 Goldie Jackson, after whom Jackson school was apparently named, says this was the first Jackson school, never Davis. Walt Dailey had told me Davis. Ruth White, first teacher, and other peninsula residents confirm Goldie's statement.

title: E.R.A. Camp North of Priest River
description: Group of kitchen workers posing for photo in front of empty tables in a dining hall at Economic Recovery Camp #102 north of Priest River.
original_description: Donor Chuck Peterson relayed this was an Economic Recovery Act camp that was established north of Priest River to make work during the Depression. According to Joe F. Naccarato, there was such a camp on Stone Johnny. The crew cleared a lot of snags in the woods. Hallie Griswold remembers no camp on Stone Johnny but says he worked in one located in the Falls Ranger Station-Four Corners vicinity. He says ite was E.R.A. Camp #102.
image_alt_text: A group of people, mostly wearing aprons and hats, stand in a kitchen with a large stove and hanging pots in the background. Tables with set plates and bottles are arranged in the foreground.

title: BRC Headquarters, Priest Lake, Idaho
description: A cabin and several tents situated among tall trees at Forest Service headquarters at Kalispell Bay.
original_description: It was both a CCC camp and a BRC camp. After this photo appeared in the PR Times, ex-Forest Service employees called to say the camp was never a headquarters (Lee White and Quentin Larson). White identified the photographer and dated the picture by the size of the trees in the foreground. They were planted after the fire of 1926 swept through the area. The camp began as a CCC camp in 1933 or '34 and became the Blister Rust Control Headquarters in 1936. The program was then administered by the Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine. The Forest Service took over the program after 1950, program phased out in 1967. Larson said that when he was there as a CCC enrollee there were two warehouses at the right by the docks. One held a boat, the Clear Joe, built by Cap Markham. The money to build the boat came from the St. Joe and Clearwater Forests' budgets, hence the name
image_alt_text: A cabin and several tents situated among tall trees, with two vintage cars parked on a dirt path.

description: A series of buildings with one house's roof bearing the word's "Falls Ranger Station". Caption at the bottom of the photograph reads: "Falls Ranger Station, 1934. Station was consolidated with the present Priest Lake Ranger Station at Nordman in 1973. At that time, it had a staff of 15-18 permanent employees and up to 25 seasonal employees. Fulton Messmore photo, courtesy Gary Weber, Priest Ranger Station. (Goes on C-8)".
original_description: House and outbuildings with lettering on roof that reads Falls Ranger Station.
image_alt_text: A group of buildings labeled "Falls Ranger Station" is surrounded by a wooden fence and trees. There is a hillside in the background, and a large sign on the primary building reads "FALLS RANGER STATION." Additional smaller buildings are nearby. Text at the bottom provides historical context and information about staff. A label near the bottom reads: "Falls Ranger Station, 1934. Station was consolidated with the present Priest Lake Ranger Station at Nordman in 1973. At that time, it had a staff of 15-18 permanent employees and up to 25 seasonal employees. Fulton Messmore photo, courtesy Gary Weber, Priest Lake Ranger Station. (Goes on C-8)"

title: Italian Internees at CCC CAMP
description: Newspaper article in the Spokane Daily News from 1943 about Italian Americans being incarcerated in former Priest River CCC Camp. Text reads: "Italian Internees Call This Spot "Home" for Duration. Lucky Italian internees, former members of Italian merchant ship crews, quartered in this former CCC camp in the beautiful Priest lake district in north Idaho, apparently are anything but dissatisfied with their lot. Pictures, taken Wednesday of this week, show the "home" surroundings for a group of prisoners of war on the peninsula road 11 miles north of Priest river. At the time the pictures were snapped, there were but two men in camp, one a ship's captain, friendly and appreciative, and a fluent speaker of English. The others, he explained to the photographer, were away at work for the day, building trails and roads."
original_description: Rogers written on back of clipping
image_alt_text: A building with a triangular roof, surrounded by trees, with a car parked nearby. Below, there is a group of buildings in a clearing with a forested hill in the background. The text describes Italian internees living in a former camp in North Idaho during 1943. Text reads: "Italian Internees Call This Spot "Home" for Duration Lucky Italian internees, former members of Italian merchant ship crews, quartered in this former CCC camp in the beautiful Priest lake district in north Idaho, apparently are anything but dissatisfied with their lot. Pictures, taken Wednesday of this week, show the "home" surroundings for a group of prisoners of war on the peninsula road 11 miles north of Priest river. At the time the pictures were snapped, there were but two men in camp, one a ship's captain, friendly and appreciative, and a fluent speaker of English. The others, he explained to the photographer, were away at work for the day, building trails and roads."

title: 1931 Fire from Leonard Brown's place
description: A rural scene with several houses surrounded by fields and trees. A large plume of smoke rises into the sky in the background.
original_description: Brown's house and farm buildings in the foreground and a huge billowing cloud of smoke in the background. The fire started near Bead and Freeman Lakes and travelled across the peninsula at incredible speed. It was the worst natural disaster ever to have befallen the Priest River Valley. Location of the Brown place is in town on the west end of Beardmore Avenue.
image_alt_text: A rural scene with several houses surrounded by fields and trees. A large plume of smoke rises into the sky in the background. A car is parked near one of the houses, and a utility pole stands near the road.

title: Green Island, Survivor
description: A small patch of green timber that survived the widespread devastation of the 1926 and 1939 burns. Following a timber sale in 1955-1956, this area was treated with a prescribed burn in the fall of 1958.
original_description: A note on the back of the original photograph, held by the Forest Service in Coeur d'Alene, identifies the location as Kalispell and Deerhorn Flats.
image_alt_text: A vast mountainous landscape with rugged hills and valleys. A patch of dense trees is nestled in an otherwise barren or lightly forested area. Several winding paths cut through the landscape. Tall, thin, bare trees are visible in the foreground.

title: Moving Out
description: Paul Croy packing out of Benton Ranger Station sitting on a horse while holding the reins, with another horse carrying a large load walking beside them.
original_description: Description with photo in sleeve says 1928. Paul never said why he was working in a clean white shirt. Croy was a teacher for 32 years, 24 of which were spent at Sandpoint High School. His parents, Arthur and Edna (Allbaugh) Croy homesteaded at Clark Fork in 1911. Paul was born in hope, Idaho on June 13, 1905.

title: Kaniksu Foresters
description: Newspaper clipping from Spokane Daily News, August 24, 1981. Text reads: "Two hundred foresters, their wives and guests attended the annual Kaniksu National Forest barn dance Friday night at Sandpoint. From left to right in the upper picture are J.E. Ryan, Kaniksu Supervisor, Bernard Anderson, Assistant Supervisor, and Clyde Webb, Missoula, Chief of the division of operations. Gifford Maryott (Left), CCC camp foreman at Usk, is seen in the lower picture receiving a helping of coffee from Lee White, Ranger at Bismark Station."
image_alt_text: Three men seated together in what appears to be a social gathering. Below, two men are engaged in serving coffee, with one pouring a cup for the other. The scene includes beams or rafters above the group in the first part. A caption below describes a forest service event. Text reads: "Two hundred foresters, their wives and guests attended the annual Kaniksu National Forest barn dance Friday night at Sandpoint. From left to right in the upper picture are J.E. Ryan, Kaniksu Supervisor, Bernard Anderson, Assistant Supervisor, and Clyde Webb, Missoula, Chief of the division of operations. Gifford Maryott (Left), CCC camp foreman at Usk, is seen in the lower picture receiving a helping of coffee from Lee White, Ranger at Bismark Station."

title: Sorting Them Out
description: A group of men stand on wooden platforms using long poles to guide logs at the Sorting Gaps on the Pend Oreille River.
original_description: Hallie Griswold said that each log as it went into the logs drive was stamped as to which company it belonged to. On the cut ends the stamp was driven in with a sledgehammer so deeply that an inch or two could be sawed off and the mark would still show. Logs were also stamped on the bark (which might slip off), and each also bore a U.S. Forest Service mark--if it was forest service timber, which most was. The Beardmore stamp was a large VIV, he said; Humbird was a big H, Fidelity a big F, Dalkena a big D and Panhandle a large P. Archivist's note: accession card notes Peterson #309-16A.
image_alt_text: A group of men stand on wooden platforms using long poles to guide logs in a river. Tall wooden posts line the platforms, and there are trees in the background.

title: Sorting Boom, Pend Oreille River
description: Several men stand on floating logs in a watery area, one holding a long pole at "The Sorting Gaps" on the Pend Oreille River.
original_description: The sorting gaps, as Arley Stewart called them, were located on the Pend Oreille, where the boat club's ramps and the grandstand are today. The logs on the drives were branded to show which mill they were to go to; they were sorted at gaps according to brands. If a mill got someone else's logs, it sawed them, wrote down the board feet and paid for them.  The shed was a barrier built in the river to break the current and to slow the logs.  There were hundreds of them up and down the river.
image_alt_text: Several men stand on floating logs in a watery area, one holding a long pole. Trees and a large wooden structure are visible in the background. Logs cover the water surface extensively.

title: The Gang in the 30s
description: Diamond log drive crew standing and sitting in a boat on a river, surrounded by logs and paddles. Handwritten text near the top reads: "The gang in the 30s Property of Bill..."
original_description: According to inscription at top, it was taken in the 30's, but Red Rouse and John Salesky give the year as 1943 or 1944. Rouse and Salesky identify the men as left to right, standing, Bill Whetsler, Leo Black, Jim Bews, Larry Gardner, Bill Dodge, Dave Bryant, Red Rouse, Jack Webb, Pete Golden, Mike Rose and Paul LaMotte. Seated in front are Sievert Flaten, Ernie Ward and Calvin Hoepfer.

title: River Pigs
description: Driving crew posed on logs in the river.
original_description: Bill Whetsler is standing at the very left end. Clarence Pingel and Eldon Gregory are also standing in the back, with Phil Prince in between them, his head at their shoulder level. To Prince's immediate right is Sievert Flaten with Henry Lund next to him on the right end. Red Rouse is kneeling on the left in front of them, in the light shirt and suspenders. Curly Golden is in front of Rouse in the dark hat, with Bud Jacobs to Golden's right, then Mart Gumaer, then two unidentified and Chet Bates on end. Others are unknown.
image_alt_text: A group of men wearing hats and outdoor clothing standing and sitting on logs by a river. The background shows trees and a hillside.

title: Log Drive Scene 1
description: Two people standing at Chipmunk Rapids during the log drive, with a steep, rocky embankment in the background.
original_description: This 3x5 horizontal was taken at Chipmunk Rapids during the log drive. Log 4-50 is almost like it. Salesky tells a story of Mart Gumaer falling off a log here while showing off for the assembled bigwigs of Diamond Match. Salesky fished him out by running his peavey under Mat's suspenders. He says Mart would rather have drowned. He characterized Mart as a show-off who was always out front garnering attention.
image_alt_text: Two people standing on logs in a river, with a steep, rocky embankment in the background.

title: Whetsler + Crew in Bateau
description: Newspaper article from the August 1, 1974 Sandpoint Idaho News-Bulletin. Text reads: "BILL WHETSLER, (left), Priest River log drive foreman for Diamond Match Co. for 18 years, from 1931 until 1949 when the drives were discontinued, guides the bateau during one of the drives which began in 1901 on Priest River. Logs were floated down the creeks into Priest Lake and then down Priest River into Pend Oreille River where they were sorted into holding pens and taken to the mills at Dover and Laclede. Mr. Whetsler, who began working in the woods when he was 15 years old, rode in the same bateau in last week's Fourth of July Parade with Mrs. Whetsler and Miss Priest River and her two princesses - Bonner County Historical Society photo."
original_description: Newspaper clipping of Bill Whetsler, facing camera + crew in the bateau in a rapid. Printed in the aug. 1, 1974, news-bulletin. Pix is in the Bonner Co. Hist. Museum.
image_alt_text: A man guiding a small boat through turbulent river waters. He is accompanied by two other individuals. The scene appears intense due to the rough waves surrounding the boat. Text reads: "BILL WHETSLER, (left), Priest River log drive foreman for Diamond Match Co. for 18 years, from 1931 until 1949 when the drives were discontinued, guides the bateau during one of the drives which began in 1901 on Priest River. Logs were floated down the creeks into Priest Lake and then down Priest River into Pend Oreille River where they were sorted into holding pens and taken to the mills at Dover and Laclede. Mr. Whetsler, who began working in the woods when he was 15 years old, rode in the same bateau in last week's Fourth of July Parade with Mrs. Whetsler and Miss Priest River and her two princesses - Bonner County Historical Society photo."
subject: logging; log drives; bateau; newspaper clippings

title: Steam Slide Ass. Loader?
description: Several workers are in a forested area engaged in logging activity in what may be Kalispell Bay.
original_description: Men loading logs in woods, cut over hill in background. Arley isn't sure what the "ass."means in the title. Chuck Peterson gave this picture, or even for sure that it was a steam rig. He thinks picture may have been taken at Kalispell Bay. There was also such a rig at Squaw Valley. It was torn out just before World War II and the iron "shipped to Japan for them to throw back at us." People named Snyder homesteaded Kalispell Bay around 1890, owned most of the bay and land the railroad in picture was on. XREF: Log 7
image_alt_text: Several workers are in a forested area engaged in logging activity. Logs are scattered across the ground and stacked on a rail car. A small structure with a roof is visible to the left, and the area is surrounded by trees and cut logs. A person can be seen operating machinery.
subject: logging; logging machinery
creator: Glenn Stewart
source: Marylyn Cork Collection, Priest River Library

title: Diamond Match Logging Train
description: A train carrying logs travels on a wooden track through a forest with tall, slender trees. Text reads: "A DIAMOND MATCH LOGGING TRAIN ENROUTE TO PRIEST LAKE WHERE THE LOGS ARE FLOATED TO THEIR DESTINATION. MILLIONS OF FEET OF WHITE PINE ARE CUT YEARLY AND MADE INTO "DIAMOND MATCHES" TO SUPPLY THE WORLD - Photo by Arthur Haines." Handwritten Text on Train: "Diamond Match Logging Train Priest Lake Region," 1929.
original_description: This picture is a copy from a 1930 calendar, photographer identified below cutline. Edith Peterson says Stanley Jones had the job of moving this train into the Priest Lake area and that Howard Peterson, Otto White and Shorty Sheridan were three of the crew. She says they skidded it on site, re enforcing the Saddler Creek bridge to do so.
image_alt_text: A train carrying logs travels on a wooden track through a forest with tall, slender trees. The forest is dense, and the train is in motion, moving away from the viewer. The ground is covered with underbrush and small plants. Text reads: "A DIAMOND MATCH LOGGING TRAIN ENROUTE TO PRIEST LAKE WHERE THE LOGS ARE FLOATED TO THEIR DESTINATION. MILLIONS OF FEET OF WHITE PINE ARE CUT YEARLY AND MADE INTO "DIAMOND MATCHES" TO SUPPLY THE WORLD - Photo by Arthur Haines." Handwritten Text on Train: "Diamond Match Logging Train Priest Lake Region", 1929.

title: Ed Elliott's Tyee & Ridley Towing Logs on Priest Lake
description: A large body of water is depicted with a collection of logs floating on its surface. In the distance, a small boat identified as the Tuee is visible towing the logs. The handwritten text at the bottom reads: "Ed Elliott's Tyee & Ridley Towing logs on Priest Lake about 1949? Elliotte Photo (B. Wetzler)." The typed text in the top right reads: "193-15A."
original_description: Information inscribed at bottom of the photo lists the photo as Elliotte's (?spelling?) with B. Whetsler in parentheses--Whetsler also misspelled. Picture shows tug towing logs. According to Don DeNooy, the Tyee was the pull boat, the Ridley was the push boat. The Ridley, which was too small to pull the big boom, pushed the small ones around and gathered them into one big boom for the Tyee. As the big boom proceeded down the lake, the Ridley was tied alongside the Tyee. Cap Elliott was their owner. He was Russ Bishop's father-in-law; Russ was the wood stoker. Boats took 4 ft. lengths.
image_alt_text: A large body of water is depicted with a collection of logs floating on its surface. In the distance, a small boat is visible towing the logs. Beyond the water, a forested shoreline is seen under a cloudy sky. Handwriting at the bottom provides information about the scene. The handwritten text at the bottom reads: "Ed Elliott's Tyee & Ridley Towing logs on Priest Lake about 1949? Elliotte Photo (B. Wetzler)." The typed text in the top right reads: ""193-15A."
subject: logging; water transportation
source: Marylyn Cork Collection, Priest River Library

title: Sundance Fire Tour Group
description: Spokane Daily Chronicle clipping, July 17, 1968. Left to right: Lee White, Gordon Trombley, Gov. Don Samuelson, Pete T. Cenarrusa. Typed text: Top left: "Spokane Daily Chronicle Wednesday, July 17, 1968." Bottom section: "Idaho officials, including (from the left) Lee L. White, president of the Priest Lake Timber Protective Association, Gordon R. Trombley, state land commissioner, Gov. Don W. Samuelson, and Pete T. Cenarrusa, secretary of state, are pictured in front of one of the planes used to tour the Sundance Mountain burn area yesterday. The tour concluded a two-day meeting called by the governor to review Idaho's preparations for another forest fire season, with emphasis on improvements."
image_alt_text: Four men standing beside an airplane, engaged in conversation. Each man is dressed in casual, business attire. One man is holding a hat in his hand. Typed text: Top left: "Spokane Daily Chronicle Wednesday, July 17, 1968." Bottom section: "Idaho officials, including (from the left) Lee L. White, president of the Priest Lake Timber Protective Association, Gordon R. Trombley, state land commissioner, Gov. Don W. Samuelson, and Pete T. Cenarrusa, secretary of state, are pictured in front of one of the planes used to tour the Sundance Mountain burn area yesterday. title: Two Million Board Feet in the Pile
description: A jumbled pile of logs (jack straw) that Clarence (Slim) Foss helped log on the Upper West Branch in the High Bridge area during the winter of 1928-1929.
original_description: He says there were over 2,000,000 board feet in the pile. Gus Naccarato was the logger for Humbird Lumber Co. The man in the white sweater at the left standing on logs toward the top of the stack was Earl Clintsman. According to Foss, log drives on the West Branch ended in 1931 after the big fire because Humbird went out of business. Logs were pulled from the pile into the river for the log drive by an old Fordson tractor. When I showed this pix to Chuck Peterson, he said the had never seen logs piled like this in this country before. Logs here were decked; they were much easier to get at that way. He said the jackstraw jumble depicted in this photo was frequently used on the coast, but not here.
image_alt_text: A large pile of cut logs stacked haphazardly, surrounded by trees in a forest setting.
subject: logging; hand logging; log decks
source: Marylyn Cork Collection, Priest River Library

title: One of the "Big Ones"
description: Loggers working in Kaniksu National Forest, with large fallen trees and foliage surrounding them, 1932.
original_description: Pix copied by U. of I. from a 1932 pictorial calendar. Cutline identifies photographer and reads: "One of the 'Big Ones.' A scene in the Kaniksu National Forest where approximately 60,000,000 timber feet are cut annually. Some 600,000 acres of forests must send their wealth through Priest River." Before the calendar was brought to Roger Gregory, Marilyn Cork at the Priest River Times received a newspaper clipping of this identical picture from Mrs. Willard C. Peterson, Sr.,  of Spokane. Mrs Peterson identified the cat skinner as her husband, Willard (Bill) Peterson, who drove cat for Fred Forsythe in the 30s. Chuck Peterson says that Diamond Match was the first logging outfit he knows of to use the detrac tractor. He says Forsythe worked for Diamond. XREF: Log 6
image_alt_text: Loggers working in a dense forest, with large fallen trees and foliage surrounding them. One person is leaning against a massive log in the foreground, while another is sitting on a piece of equipment nearby. Tall trees form the background, creating an overall rugged and natural setting.
subject: logging; hand logging
source: Marylyn Cork Collection, Priest River Library

title: Breaking a Log Jam at Mouth of Priest River
description: A large number of logs completely covering the mouth of Priest River, 1930.
original_description: Picture made from Naida Miller's 1930 calendar by the U. of I. Photo Lab. Cutline under pix read "A log jam at the mouth of Priest River where the loads are held and sorted for the various mills. This jam is approx. 1 mile in length, a part of which is within the limits of Priest River. A new steel bridge on the state highway now under construction will be located at this point." Steel bridge built in 1927. Other data on calendar stated that Priest River had 6 lumbering and cedar products companies and that 1 company treated and shipped 500 carloads of cedar products annually.
image_alt_text: A large number of logs with trees and hills in the background.

title: Logs on Wagon With Child
description: Steven B. Marvin (on wheel), three men and a child stand next to a large log on a wagon with big wooden wheels. One man is leaning on the log with a tool, and the child is sitting on the log.
original_description: It was made from  a postcard that was addressed to a W. J. Marvin (1st initial is not clearly legible, may be something else), Millbank, J.J. but it was never mailed. Inscription says "My father out in Wash. 1909, and "Walters" is written below it. According to donor, this postcard was purchased by her grandfather, Steven B. Marvin, who had come from Minnesota to work out here. He is the man standing on the rear wagon wheel, whom someone has boxed off with a pen. The postcard was addressed to Marvin's son, Helen Elliott's father, back east, who came out here himself later.
